embeds.title: Quest 2 Straps
embeds.description: The Quest 2 supports modular head straps, and as such, many accessories are available. In the dropdown below, you can see details on several straps, including photos.

fields.name: BOBOVR M2 Pro
fields.value: The BOBOVR M2 Pro is a popular halo-style strap with a built-in battery.

fields.name: Kiwi Elite Strap
fields.value: The Kiwi Elite Strap is similar to the official Elite Strap but without the cracking issue of the official strap, and is known to be comfortable.

fields.name: Vive Deluxe Audio Strap
fields.value: The Vive Deluxe Audio Strap is a solution using a strap designed for a Vive with integrated audio, but is quite costly.

embeds.title: BOBOVR M2 Pro
embeds.description:
The BOBOVR M2 PRO is a 'halo' style strap that's relatively new and a successor to the BOBOVR M2, but has an included hotswappable battery.

It's a bit harder to find due to the battery but is generally known to be a good overall choice for comfort and value compared to other options like the Elite Battery Strap.

embeds.description:
The Kiwi Elite Strap is an upgraded strap in the style of the official Elite Strap with a nice cushioned top and head cushion.
 One of the main benefits of this is that it's able to fit in the official case and third party cases.

embeds.title: Vive Deluxe Audio Strap
embeds.description:
The Vive Deluxe Audio Strap is a popular strap due to the integrated audio. However, it is not as popular as it once was due to pricing. 
 The Quest 2 has modular strap attachments that support third party straps designed specifically for Quest 2, and as such, other straps like the BOBOVR and Kiwi have been made for far cheaper.

 You can get a Vive Deluxe Audio Strap for $100 typically, but you also need a 3D-printed adapter. 
 If you do not have a 3D printer, you will have to pay upwards of $20 for the adapter.

embed.title: Community Tested Routers
embed.description:
The following routers have been reported to work reliably from a number of users.
High End (AXE / WiFi 6E) - TP-Link AXE300/AXE16000 ($450 US)
High End (AX / WiFi 6) - Asus RT-AX86U ($300 US)
Dedicated (BE / Wifi 7) - TP-Link BE9300/BE550 ($200-$300 US)
Dedicated (AXE / WiFi 6E) - Davolink 'Kevin' Minion 6E ($129 US)
Dedicated (AXE / WiFi 6E) - TP-Link Archer AXE75/AXE5400 ($160-$200 US)
Dedicated AP (AXE / WiFi 6E) - ARRIS Surfboard W6U (single port)
Network Bridge (AXE / WiFi 6E) - ARRIS Surfboard Thruster W6B (2-piece kit)
Dedicated (AX) - PRISMXR Puppis S1 (80$)
Dedicated (AX / WiFi 6) - GL.iNet Beryl GL-MT3000 ($90 US)
Low End (AC / WiFi 5) - GL.iNet Opal GL-SFT1200 ($50 US)
Low End (AC / WiFi 5) - TP-Link Archer C6 or A6 ($40 US)

TP-Link AX and Huawei routers have been known to have issues we are unable to identify. Higher end TP-Link AX/AXE routers not listed here may work well but as with any router not on this list, should be considered untested.
The TP-Link Archer AXE5400 is not the same thing as the Deco AXE5400. The latter is a mesh router and may not work as expected.

embed.title: Quest New User Guide
embed.description: Please select a section to start

embeds.title: So you just got it out of the box, now what?

fields.name: Charge
fields.value: Plug in your quest to charge, so after everything is ready you have plenty of battery!

fields.name: Create your account
fields.value: Make your Meta account if you haven't already on the Mobile app.

fields.name: Referrals
fields.value:
Redeem any referrals you got from friends on your Oculus App (only works before activation), or if you need one you can use <#927288276673523782>
 for more information please check out the referrals option.

fields.name: Video Guide
fields.value: Follow the [video guide](https://youtu.be/ZBSiZ5Pcjjg) by Oculus, this will help get you setup in your new Quest.

embeds.title: What are Referrals?
embeds.description:
When setting up a Meta Quest Device you can use a referral to gain a free $30 in-store credit for the Meta store.
This has to be done BEFORE setting up the device but can be done with a pre-existing account, this also gives a $30 credit to the provider of the referral link.

fields.name: How can a friend send me a referral?
fields.value:
Your friend must first add you as a friend on their Quest Account and then generate a referral link in the Meta Quest app:
1. Go to the Meta Quest app.
2. Tap your Avatar at the bottom.
3. Click the three lines at the top-right corner.
4. Scroll down and find **Referrals** (diamond icon).
5. Use the large blue box to start the referral process.

fields.name: What can be referred?
fields.value:
The referral program includes **Devices**, **Games**, and **Meta Quest+ Subscription**. 
**Important:** If you own Meta Quest+, you are unable to share or use App Referrals.

fields.name: Additional Details
fields.value: Device referrals provide $30 credits to both parties after device setup. App referrals give up to **15% discounts to recipients** and small credit rewards (e.g., $6) to referrers. Certain pricing and use limits apply.

embeds.title: Anything I should avoid?
embeds.description: As you are new to VR, there are a few things you should consider.

fields.name: Guardian
fields.value:
Make sure you set your guardian in a nice open area with nothing to hit
 I'd personally advise you give a little buffer on top, when your new it's pretty easy to get a bit excited and swing past the guardian as well.

fields.name: Sunlight
fields.value: Make sure you keep the lenses (the part you look into, not the cameras) away from direct sun, as that can burn the displays inside the headset rather quickly.

fields.name: Sickness
fields.value: If you start to feel sick, make sure you take breaks! Pushing through it can make it worse in a lot of cases.

fields.name: Cleaning the lenses
fields.value: Make sure you don't use any cleaning liquids on your lenses, and only use microfiber cloths.

pages.name: What else can I do with my quest?

embeds.title: What else can I do?
embeds.description: Looking through the store and can't find something that suits you?

fields.name: Other stores
fields.value: You can check out games on [Sidequest](https://sidequestvr.com/setup-howto)! There's some great titles like Dr. Beef's large library of ports from older PC games.

fields.name: Explore
fields.value: Explore the world in [Wooorld](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/4360608937312293) with friends.

fields.name: Watch Something
fields.value: You can try 3D Movies out in [Bigscreen](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/2497738113633933/), either with new friends or old, go solo in Meta Quest TV and check out their collection or join a live event in [Horizon Worlds](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/2532035600194083/).

fields.name: Productivity
fields.value: You can be productive, use it as a virtual computer with multi tasking with browsers, or connected to a computer with programs like [Workrooms](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/2514011888645651), [Virtual Desktop](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/2017050365004772), [vSpacial](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/2540393919317658), and [Immersed](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/2849273531812512/)

fields.name: PCVR
fields.value: You can also play PC VR games with a [VR Ready PC](https://support.oculus.com/articles/headsets-and-accessories/oculus-link/oculus-link-compatibility/)!

embeds.title: PCVR
embeds.description: As long as you have a VR Ready PC, you can play PC VR either wired or wireless! This does include SteamVR Games as well.

fields.name: Wired
fields.value: You can play wired PC VR using Oculus Link and a USB 3.0 cable.

fields.name: Wireless
fields.value: You can play wirelessly using [Air Link](https://support.oculus.com/airlink/), [Virtual Desktop](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/2017050365004772/), [Steam Link](https://www.meta.com/experiences/5841245619310585/) or [ALVR](https://github.com/alvr-org/ALVR).

fields.name: Where should I buy my games for PCVR?
fields.value: A lot of people prefer Steam, and most people agree - however I would check to see if the game is [crossbuy](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/section/2335732183153590/#/?_k=l5u635) before you buy on steam, as a 'crossbuy' title you can buy on Quest and get on the Rift store and Quest store. (PC and Quest at the same time).

embeds.title: Discounts
embeds.description: Your just in luck, there are many ways to find discounts for games!

fields.name: Meta Store
fields.value: The Meta Store always has *something* on-sale, you can find this via going into the store, and using the *On-Sale* filter, on both the desktop, in-headset, and app, or you can view the 'Sales' tab if your in-headset!

fields.name: Reddit
fields.value: The wonderful users of the OculusQuest subreddit have compiled a [**Mega-Thread**](https://www.reddit.com/r/OculusQuest/comments/1ed8b5a/discounted_games_megathread/) of current games that have codes, this list is always updating, so check back frequently if your eyeing a game!

fields.name: Referrals / Creator Codes
fields.value: Referrals and Creator Codes are your second best friend if none of the above has something for the specific game your looking for, Referrals give 15% off a game, but require you to be friends with the user, and Creator Codes give 10% off a game, and can be used at any time by any one, you just need to find one, usually YouTubers will put these in the descriptions of their videos.

embeds.title: Support
embeds.description: If you are having issues with your Quest, please check out <#1030166436297064510>

embed.title: Support is volunteer-driven
embed.description:
Be patient, be civil, and be descriptive about your issues.

All support is volunteer driven, we help who we can as we can. Not everyone knows how to help you, and not everyone will. Avoid pinging staff directly, they are volunteers too and will assist when possible.

Be as descriptive as you can with your issue; it's a lot more likely someone will remember something if they see a keyword that helps them.

fields.name: Ask in One Channel
fields.value: Posting the same issue in multiple channel leads to confusion, reduces the willingness of volunteers to assist, and does not accelerate response times. Stick to #support channels for each issue.

pages.name: Do I keep my games after cancelling?
pages.title: Do I keep my games after cancelling?

embeds.title: Do I keep my games after cancelling?
embeds.description:
No, just like Xbox Gamepass or PlayStation Plus, you lose access to your games once your month is over, until your month is over you will have access to your games however.
 As soon as you resubscribe, you'll regain access to all claimed games, regardless if it's still their month or not.

 To check if there is a current trial, check your Meta Quest + dashboard.

name: ipd
description: IPD and Its Importance in VR.

embed.title: IPD and Its Importance in VR.
embed.description: IPD is the distance between the pupils of your eyes. This is important for VR as you need to make sure you are within the supported IPD range of a headset, otherwise you will experience eye strain, focus issues, and other related issues.

fields.name: Common IPD Ranges
fields.value:
Quest 2 - 3 Settings - 58mm, 63mm, 68mm (+/-2.5mm in each direction)
Valve Index - 58-70mm
Reverb G2 - 60-68mm
[VRCompare for more headsets](https://vr-compare.com/)

fields.name: How to check?
fields.value:
There are a few ways to check, but the two main methods are measuring with a ruler in front of a mirror or using the app [EyeMeasure](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/eyemeasure/id1417435049)
 You want the 'Far' IPD from this app.

fields.name: Ruler Method
fields.value:
Stand in front of a mirror and hold a ruler up to your nose, such that the measuring edge runs directly underneath both your pupils.
Close your right eye and look directly at your left eye. Move the ruler so that the 0 mark appears directly underneath the center of your left pupil. Try to keep the ruler still for the next step.
Close your left eye and look directly at your right eye. The mark directly underneath the center of your right pupil is your IPD.

embed.title: General Minimum Specs for VR
embed.description:
OS: Windows 10
CPU: Intel i5-7500 / AMD Ryzen 5 1600 or greater
RAM: 12GB+ RAM
GPU: NVIDIA GTX 1660 Super / AMD Radeon RX 5600XT or greater
USB Ports: 1x 3.1 port
Free Space: 35GB on C:

fields.name: Detailed Info
fields.value:
You can find detailed minimums below, please note minimum does not mean you can play every game.
[Oculus Rift S Supported Specs](https://store.facebook.com/help/quest/articles/getting-started/getting-started-with-rift/rift-s-minimum-requirements/)
[Oculus Link Supported Specs](https://store.facebook.com/help/quest/articles/headsets-and-accessories/oculus-link/oculus-link-compatibility/)
[Valve Index Supported Specs](https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=4061-QUZB-4602)

embed.title: Sidequest
embed.description: Sidequest is a widely known application that allows you to 'sideload' third-party apps and modifications to your Quest.

fields.name: Do I need a VR-ready PC?
fields.value: No, it does not require a VR-ready PC to use, but does require a cable to connect your Quest to your PC (2.0 or 3.0) for the advanced functionality, if you want to install games without using a computer, you can also install it onto your headset however it's use is limited.

fields.name: What does it hold?
fields.value: Not only does it hold third-party apps, such as mods and fangames, you can also change your recording values, and install mods and apks directly to your headset via your PC.

fields.name: How do I install it onto my Quest?
fields.value: The folks at Sidequest have made a handy tutorial to help with this, please [watch it here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LhOJBTwJ-40)

fields.name: Is it safe?
fields.value: It is accepted (and even endorsed) by Meta and you can find information on how to install it [here](https://sidequestvr.com/setup-howto) with all setup instructions.

embed.title: Oculus Link
embed.description: Oculus Link is a feature built into the Quest that allows you to use your Quest as a PC VR headset while wired into a VR-ready PC.

fields.name: Can I play any VR game?
fields.value: You can generally play any Oculus Rift or SteamVR title while on Link, as long as your PC is capable of running it.

fields.name: What's required?
fields.value:
You need a VR-ready PC that meets the minimum specs, you can find out more details [here](https://support.oculus.com/444256562873335/) as well as a USB 3.0 A-to-C or C-to-C cable.
 You can find more info about this with /linkcables.

embed.title: Air Link
embed.description: Air Link is the wireless PCVR feature introduced in [V28](https://www.oculus.com/blog/introducing-oculus-air-link-a-wireless-way-to-play-pc-vr-games-on-oculus-quest-2-plus-infinite-office-updates-support-for-120-hz-on-quest-2-and-more/)

fields.name: Requirements
fields.value:
1. [VR-Ready PC](https://support.oculus.com/444256562873335), please note this is not 100% of all hardware supported; better graphics cards than listed will work as well. 
2. 5GHz AC or AX network with a wired connection to your PC.

fields.name: FAQ
fields.value:
1. **Is my internet good enough?:** Internet does not matter for Air Link, you only need a good local connection.
2. **Can I play SteamVR on this?:** Yes, SteamVR is fully supported just like wired link.
3. **Is my router good enough?:** If you want more information, look up your router's model number and make sure it's AX or AC, or provide your model number in your help thread.
4. **I'm having issues, where can I get help?:** Please create a thread using #support.

embed.title: Sharing Screenshots of the Performance Overlay
embed.description:
1.) Go into the Settings tab in the Virtual Desktop menu in VR and make sure 'copy screenshots to desktop' is enabled.
2.) Go into the Streaming tab and check 'Show performance overlay'.
3.) Launch your VR game.
4.) Look for numbers that are turning orange.
5.) When you see this, hold right Oculus button and press right trigger or left trigger to take a screenshot.

 The screenshot will be found on your desktop and you can share it here.

embed.title: Quest USB/Link
embed.description:
Connecting your Quest VR headset with your VR ready PC using a USB cable allows you to play VR games from your PC, this includes Oculus rift games and Steam games. However, when purchasing a cable there are a few things to take into account: 

**USB Connection types**
USB cables can come with multiple different connector types, the ones you want to be looking for are USB type A and USB type C. All current Quest devices use a USB C port, which means that your cable needs to have at least *one* USB C connector, the other end can be either A or C; other than their shape and respective port they offer no real difference in this use case and they will perform the same.

**USB standards**
USB standards (data speed simply said) are important for link cables, any link cable used for any of the Quest devices should be USB 3.0, also known as USB 3.1 Gen 1, and USB 3.2 Gen 1x1.
Note that USB 2.0 will provide a very poor experience so avoid using those.
You can find these types of cables on A and C through various retailers at various lengths, performance-wise they are all equal.

**Length**
For an optimal experience you ideally want a cable that is 3-5m long, generally it is not recommended that USB 2.0/3.0 cables are longer than that.

**Battery time with a USB cable**
Playtime will be increased using a cable, but it is not guaranteed that the cable provides infinite playtime. This is a limitation of many motherboards and the cable plays no role.

For cable recommendations with detailed descriptions, use /linkcables.

embed.title: Inside Out Body Tracking
embed.description:
Meta's Inside Out Body Tracking IOBT for the Quest 2 and 3 is a technology that tracks the user's upper body movements using the headset's cameras. This feature allows the VR system to accurately display the user's arms and torso movements in VR. 

Meta has an inside out body tracking demo you can try [here](https://www.meta.com/experiences/6511679575602893/). This is also used on Virtual Desktop for Full Body Tracking on SteamVR.

AMD 5000/6000/7000/9000 series: [25.10.2](https://www.amd.com/en/resources/support-articles/release-notes/RN-RAD-WIN-25-10-2.html)

embed.title: Uninstall and Reinstall GPU Drivers
embed.description:
Follow these steps to uninstall GPU drivers using DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller):
1. Download DDU from the [official website](https://www.guru3d.com/files-details/display-driver-uninstaller-download.html) and download the GPU driver you intend to install (see below).
2. Reboot your PC into [Safe Mode](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/start-your-pc-in-safe-mode-in-windows-92c27cff-db89-8644-1ce4-b3e5e56fe234)
3. Launch DDU and select the GPU from the list.
4. Click on 'Clean and restart'.
5. After the process and restart, the GPU drivers will be uninstalled.

You can then reinstall the reccomended drivers, to check the latest recommendations type /drivers.

embed.title: Please provide more information
embed.description:
All support is volunteer, to be able to have people help it's best if you could provide more information about your computer or issue. 
 Please provide relevent computer information such as your CPU, Graphics Card, and Operating System.
 Additionally, any information you could see to be helpful to further assist, if this is airlink or vd related, your network setup such as router model, and if you are wired can help in these cases too.
 
[You can also contact Oculus before reaching out to the community for help.](https://tickets.oculusvr.com/hc/en-us/requests/new)

embed.title: Virtual Desktop
embed.description:
Virtual Desktop is a Quest application that allows you to use your desktop in VR, watch videos, as well as use it for wireless PC VR with a VR-ready PC.
For first-time setup and general FAQ, please check out [this guide](https://reddit.com/r/OculusQuest/wiki/faq/virtualdesktop), if you need further help, please visit their [Discord](https://discord.gg/fzvaHfpneH)

embed.title: Quest/Rift Cross-Buy Apps
embed.description:
Rift and Quest have some games that support cross-buy, and you can find that list [here](https://www.oculus.com/experiences/quest/section/2335732183153590/#/?_k=l5u635).
 Please note that cross-buy can only apply between Meta PC and Quest stores, and this does not include any other platform.

embed.title: Extended Reality (XR)
embed.description:
Extended Reality (XR) covers all the different ways we mix computer technology with our real world. Here's what that includes:

**Virtual Reality (VR)**: This is like stepping into a different world. You wear a headset, and everything you see is created by a computer. It's used for video games and other interactive experiences.

**Augmented Reality (AR)**: This adds computer-created elements to the real world. If you've played games where characters appear in the real world on your phone screen, or used a filter to add a hat to your selfie, that's AR!

**Mixed Reality (MR)**: This is a blend of AR and VR. Here, virtual objects are added to the real world and can interact with it. It's like having virtual objects in your living room that you can move and touch.

embed.title: Quest/Rift Crossplay Apps
embed.description:
Rift and Quest have some games that support crossplay (playing multiplayer between different platforms (Steam, Rift, Quest, and/or PSVR)), and you can find that list [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/oculus/wiki/crossplay).
Please note that this is a community-maintained list and will not always be accurate. (Usually outdated)

embed.title: Valve Support
embed.description: You can contact Valve via a ticket [here](https://help.steampowered.com/en/wizard/HelpWithGame/?appid=250820).

embed.title: Oculus/Meta Support
embed.description: You can contact Oculus Support via either a ticket or live chat [here](https://store.facebook.com/help/support/quest/).

embed.title: Quest Manual Update
embed.description: You can find a guide on how to manually update [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/oculusquest/wiki/guides/manualupdate). You will also need a copy of the firmware you want to update to.

embed.title: Internet isn't used when streaming
embed.description: Once your VR headset is connected to your computer, all data traffic remains local. This is true whether you're connected directly to your main router or to a dedicated router on the same local area network (LAN). The only requirement is a wired connection from your PC to a router. The VR headset then connects wirelessly to the same router or dedicated router.

embed.title: Don't ask to ask; just ask
embed.description:
When you ask 'Hey can anyone help me?', this can be seen as bad form.
 The best way to get assistance is to ask your entire question, with details, in a relevant channel.
 There are plenty of reasons why people that do have the knowledge would not admit to it, but by asking the full question you are asking people to answer a question, not take responsibility to answer the question they may not have the answer to.

embed.title: Half-Life: Alyx - Stutter Fix
embed.description: Right-click Half-Life: Alyx in Steam then click Properties, in 'General' click in 'Launch Options', and paste the following: ```+vr_fidelity_level_auto 0 +vr_fidelity_level 3```

embed.title: Quest Factory Reset
embed.description: If you need to factory reset your Quest, follow [these](https://www.meta.com/help/quest/articles/fix-a-problem/troubleshoot-headsets-and-accessories/troubleshooting-factory-reset-quest/) instructions on the factory reset.

embed.title: Quest Cloud Backup
embed.description: You can see what games you own that support cloud backup [here](https://secure.oculus.com/my/cloud-backup/).

embed.title: Wireless PCVR Streaming: AirLink vs Virtual Desktop vs Steam Link
embed.description: A comprehensive comparison of the three main wireless PCVR streaming solutions for Quest headsets.

fields.name: Quick Verdict
fields.value:
**Best Overall**: Virtual Desktop ($24.99) - Most reliable and feature-rich
**Best Free Option**: Steam Link - Simple setup, good performance
**Alternative**: AirLink - Built-in but less reliable

**Tip**: Try Steam Link first, then consider Virtual Desktop for advanced features.

**AirLink**: Problematic
**Virtual Desktop**: Consistent
**Steam Link**: Consistent

embeds.title: Meta AirLink - Official Free Solution
embeds.description: Built into Quest headsets, AirLink is Meta's official wireless PCVR streaming.

fields.name: Pros
fields.value:
Completely free
- Built into Quest - no extra downloads
- Simple setup process
- Works with all Oculus PC content
- Supports Link Cable for wired option
- Official Meta support

fields.name: Cons
fields.value:
Frequent stuttering/lag issues
- Limited customization options
- Higher PC resource usage
- Less reliable than alternatives
- Minimal configuration options

fields.name: Performance Details
fields.value:
**Quality**: Good when working properly
- **Stability**: Inconsistent, varies by setup
- **Bitrate**: Up to 700 Mbps (on H.264 with debug edits)
- **CPU Usage**: Higher than alternatives

fields.name: Use AirLink When
fields.value:
Playing Oculus-exclusive games
- You need wired Link Cable option
- Other solutions aren't available
- Testing basic PCVR functionality

footer.text: Verdict: Free but less reliable than alternatives

embeds.title: Virtual Desktop - Premium Wireless Solution
embeds.description: The most feature-rich and reliable wireless PCVR streaming option.

fields.name: Pros
fields.value:
Best overall performance
- SSW (frame generation)
- Super Resolution upscaling
- Multiple codec options
- VDXR runtime (+10% performance)
- Bitrates up to 500 Mbps
- Regular updates
- Multi-monitor streaming
- Most customization options

fields.name: Cons
fields.value:
Costs $24.99
- Learning curve for settings
- Minor game compatibility issues
- No cable support
- More complex initial setup

fields.name: Exclusive Features
fields.value:
**SSW**: Headset-based frame generation
- **SGSR**: Qualcomm upscaling technology
- **VDXR**: Custom OpenXR runtime
- **Codecs**: H.264+, HEVC, AV1 10-bit
- **Body Tracking**: Full passthrough support
- **Hand Tracking**: Index controller emulation

fields.name: Use Virtual Desktop When
fields.value:
You want the best performance
- Playing demanding games (sims)
- You need advanced features
- Maximum customization desired
- $24.99 fits your budget

footer.text: Verdict: Worth the price for serious PCVR users

embeds.title: Steam Link - Valve's Free Alternative
embeds.description: Native Steam VR streaming app, a solid free option for wireless PCVR.

fields.name: Pros
fields.value:
Completely free
- Plug-and-play setup
- No Oculus software needed
- Direct Steam VR integration
- Simple, clean interface
- Good performance
- Easiest setup process

fields.name: Cons
fields.value:
Wireless only (no cable)
- Some users report stuttering
- Limited configuration options
- Newer, less mature
- Only for Steam content
- Fewer features than VD

fields.name: Performance Details
fields.value:
**Quality**: Good compression
- **Stability**: Generally reliable
- **Setup**: Easiest of all three
- **Compatibility**: Steam VR only
- **Resource Usage**: Moderate

fields.name: Use Steam Link When
fields.value:
You primarily play Steam VR games
- You want a free solution
- Simple setup is priority
- You're new to wireless PCVR
- Avoiding Oculus software

footer.text: Verdict: Best free option for most users

embed.title: PCVR Streaming Alternatives
embed.description:
If you're using Meta/Oculus Link (wired or Air Link) for PCVR, consider switching to something else.

**The Problems:**
Meta Link has constant issues with updates, random disconnects and crashes, visual artifacts, and a general lack of maintenance since PCVR users typically buy games on Steam anyway.

**What to Use Instead:**
**Virtual Desktop** (~$25 on Quest Store)
The gold standard for wireless PCVR. Better customization, reliability, and actively maintained. "It just works."

**Steam Link** (Free)
Valve's official solution with good performance. Will be the native option for the upcoming Steam Frame headset.

**ALVR** (Free, Open Source)
Completely free alternative. Less user-friendly but very capable if you like tinkering.

**Note:** Wireless PCVR doesn't require fast internet - it only needs a good local network. All streaming happens between your PC and headset on your LAN.
